Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Directed Self-Assembly of Linear and Star Block Copolymer Thin Films - Oriented Nanostructures with Reduced Feature Sizes via Raster Annealing
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

This research aims to address the challenge of manufacturing lower cost, more efficient, lighter weight, and smaller scale systems for applications ranging from information or data storage devices for digital media to portable biosensing arrays that could potentially screen and treat a myriad of diseases. The project integrates fundamental research with collaborative assistance from an industrial partner to generate nanoscale features (of order 1/1000th the width of a human hair) that have potential to be translated from the laboratory-scale to a widely available and useable platform. In undertaking this collaborative approach, the research team will use commercially-relevant polymers that are created to spontaneously form ultra-small features, whose shape and function can be dictated through processing conditions. By linking aspects of materials chemistry, materials properties, and processing, this project will aid in the cost-effective evaluation of polymer systems to generated efficient electronic devices. This project provides research opportunities to students (including underrepresented undergraduate and economically-disadvantaged high school students) in a vibrant and collaborative laboratory setting and exposes students of all levels to cutting-edge concepts for making new nanometer scale materials that could lead to lower cost and more energy-efficient fabrication of computer-related devices.



TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

The PI and his industrial partner at DuPont collaborate to develop new nanotemplates from self-assembling macromolecules using commercially-relevant block copolymers. A particular goal of this work is to investigate star architectures (and variable block chemistries) in block copolymers as a viable means for generating "writeable" and oriented nanostructures with reduced feature sizes for nanotemplating applications. By accomplishing this goal, the University of Delaware and DuPont team will address key needs in the arena of nanotemplating and bit-patterned media, including the ability to rapidly generate thin film templates with well-defined features at low cost, with appropriate and addressable orientations and domains, with minimal defects, and approaching smaller feature sizes (< 5 nm). To facilitate general understanding, the proposed activities combine 1) the examination of various block copolymer architectures and chemistries, 2) the development of a unique solvent vapor annealing approach (raster solvent vapor annealing with soft shear), and 3) the macromolecular design, synthesis, self-assembly, and characterization expertise of the University of Delaware and the nanoprocessing and materials expertise of DuPont. Specific research themes include: (1) investigating the differences between star and linear block copolymer directed self-assembly using both moderately-repulsive and highly-repulsive polymer-polymer interactions to reduce feature sizes, improve nanostructure ordering, and control nanostructure orientation; (2) utilizing a newly-developed directed and programmable solvent annealing process to directionally align nanostructures with minimal defects; (3) probing solvent partitioning between domains via neutron scattering techniques; (4) incorporating newly-proposed "flexible-blade" flow coating to simultaneously cast and align nanostructures.

ProgramReference.Text: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS
EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
A major aim of this project was to tackle the challenge of manufacturing lower-cost, more efficient, lighter-weight, and smaller-scale systems for applications ranging from information or data storage devices for digital media to portable biosensing arrays that can screen and treat a myriad of diseases. For this effort, commercially relevant, nanostructure-forming, block copolymers were employed, with both linear and star-like chain architectures as a means for generating 'writeable' and orientable nanostructures with reduced features sizes for templating applications. The activities combined 1) the comparison of various copolymer chemistries and architectures capable of promoting molecular assembly, 2) the development of unique thin-film processing routes to increase the efficiency of nanostructure manufacturing processes, and 3) the investigation of new multi-step fabrication approaches to eliminate waste and improve sustainability. Each of the above tasks leveraged a collaborative relationship between the University of Delaware and DuPont to strengthen synthesis, characterization, development, and outreach activities. Overall, the project made substantial inroads into understanding and manipulating the self-assembly of polymer thin films, including the realization of routes to control the nanoscale orientation and alignment of nanostructures at much faster speeds than conventional thermal annealing, as well as the design and proof-of-principle testing of new coating tools/process to simultaneously deposit and orient polymer films.

 

Intellectual Merit:

Through the National Science Foundation's GOALI program, several novel polymers were synthesized and characterized, and scalable, efficient, and more sustainable processes were developed. These tasks were accomplished through a multidisciplinary approach that integrated polymer chemistry, nanomaterials design, understanding of structure-property relationships, and process engineering. One salient example of project success was the demonstration of directional alignment of perpendicular lamellae (sheets) in highly incompatible block copolymers, in which the alignment and orientation was facilitated by a combination of a three-armed star chain architecture and solvent-based processing - without any thermal annealing or substrate surface modifications. Additional efforts on this star polymer system suggested that the architecture increased the propensity for nanoscale phase separation, which should facilitate the realization of the reduced feature sizes that are ideal for next-generation lithographic applications. Another example of translatable project outcomes was the demonstration of a rapid, single-step technique to align block polymer, thin-film nanostructures that is amenable to continuous speeds ≥10 mm/s. This method can enable high-throughput, large-area manufacturing of patterns such as nanowire templates and is 50x faster existing processes. Furthermore, it can be leveraged for cost-effective manufacturing of macroscopically aligned nanostructures in continuous, roll-to-roll systems with reduced solvent usage. Key results were highlighted in multiple publications in the peer-reviewed literature, patents and patent applications, oral and poster presentations to the scientific and local community, and collaborative scientific activities with other research groups.

 

Broader Impacts:

In addition to generating greater understanding of new nanostructure-forming polymers that are ideal for lithography and membrane applications, major results of the project have led to peer-reviewed publications and intellectual property generation associated with the rapid, efficient, and more sustainable processing of polymer thin films for nanotemplate formation. Graduate students and postdoctoral researchers working on this project have moved on to Dow/DuPont, faculty positions in the U.S. and abroad, and national laboratories. Furthermore, project personnel engaged in a variety of educational and outreach activities that had a substantial and positive impact on the community. For example, Dow/DuPont researchers have taught graduate and undergraduate students about the impact of polymer properties on materials fabrication as part of an Introduction to Polymer Science course. Over 150 students have attended these lectures. Additionally, economically disadvantaged high school students, undergraduate students, and graduate student mentors were able to take in-person and virtual field trips to Dow/DuPont facilities to gain a visual perspective of cutting-edge polymeric materials research & development and manufacturing. A particular focus was links between polymer science, processing, and data management. During this project, the high school and undergraduate programs directly impacted approximately 50 students. Dow/DuPont personnel also led discussions on sustainability and polymer waste; over 200 people attended these free events about how industry is developing and modifying strategies to minimize waste in products and processing - linking engineering, economics, and society considerations.
